thread.title: Legend Jeff Jarrett reveals how he is ready to tap into the UK wrestling scene to make Impact great again
thread.title_full: Legend Jeff Jarrett reveals how he is ready to tap into the UK wrestling scene to make Impact great again

author: gstonehouse
title: Legend Jeff Jarrett reveals how he is ready to tap into the UK wrestling scene to make Impact great again
text:
Other Sports 'HOTTEST SCENE IN THE WORLD' Legend Jeff Jarrett reveals how he is ready to tap into the UK wrestling scene to make Impact great again 
In part one of SunSport's exclusive interview with the iconic wrestler he explains his future plans after returning to Impact Exclusive Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window) Comments WRESTLING legend Jeff Jarrett has exclusively revealed how he is ready to tap into the “hottest scene in the world” in the United Kingdom to help “make Impact great again”. 
The 49-year-old is back with the US-based promotion as Executive Producer and is already plotting the rise of the company again. 12 Wrestling legend Jeff Jarrett met SunSport’s Gary Stonehouse for an exclusive chat in London on Friday 
Jarrett was a co-founder of Total Nonstop Action Wrestling in 2003 and played a huge role in and out of the ring as the brand’s popularity grew around the world, with a star-studded roster that included now WWE superstars AJ Styles and Samoa Joe. 
Keep up to date with ALL the SPORT news and gossip at SunSport online 
Since his departure from TNA in 2014, things have not ran smoothly for the organisation, but having recently returned to the re-branded Impact, an exciting future looks to lay in wait for Jarrett and co. 
And while speaking to SunSport during a trip to London, Jarrett spoke of his excitement at the prospects ahead and how the UK wrestling scene is one of his “top priorities”. Related stories Sleepy Lee...but will the defender's error cost his side? ROAR EMOTION Sutton striker Roarie Deacon has a photo of him signing for Arsenal pride of place in his home... now he is back in the frame for Arsene Wenger BALLS-UP FA hit Leyton Orient's Liam Kelly with six-match ban for pushing over Plymouth ballboy Beer we go All hands to the pump as Sutton United order 6,000 extra pint glasses for visit of Arsenal APPLE'S BEARING FRUIT Michael Appleton passes Oxford exam as he eyes Boro KO after beating Newcastle 
“It’s the hottest scene in the world, without question,” said Jarrett. 
“It’s something that is not a surprise to me as I saw it several years ago. There were independent promotions that were doing things right but it takes a while to come into place. 
“But it’s the hottest scene in the world, the talent is here and it is high on the agenda of myself and Ed, the president of Anthem Wrestling. Getty Images Jeff Jarrett is back at Impact wrestling and is determined to ‘make it great again’ WWE Jeff Jarrett says UK wrestling is ‘the hottest scene in the world’ right now WWE 12 Jeff Jarrett went on to enjoy worldwide fame throughout his wrestling career after breaking onto the scene with WWE in the 1990s 
“We’ve got our work cut out, but it’s exciting to re-energise and the UK is a top priority for us.” 
Jarrett shot to worldwide fame during the 1990s after joining WWE, then named WWF, and was a six-time Intercontinental champion. 
He went onto to become a four-time World Heavyweight champ at rivals WCW before launching the storied chapter of his career with TNA. 
Famed for bashing his opponents over the head with a guitar, Jarrett was and still remains one of the biggest names in wrestling. 
And although he says “never say never” when quizzed whether we will see his instrument-swinging antics in the ring again, these days he is more focused on unearthing the next big star. 
Jarrett explained: “My family has been in the business for 70 years, so hearing the stories from a very young age, that’s part of the business. 
“I was a fan first, then I became a wrestler, then a promoter then a businessman and everything that goes with it – marketing, merchandise, licensing, legal, everything. But I’ve always enjoyed it. 
“Go back to 2002 when Impact was launched with a young guy from North Georgia AJ Styles and another from Toronto named Bobby Roode, then Samoa Joe came along, Eric Young… I could go on and on. 
“Those guys have gone on to be hot attractions and AJ is the hottest attraction. That’s something that I take a lot of pride in.” 
He continued: “Being back with Impact wrestling, I couldn’t be happier for those guys, but from a professional and business side, it energises me so much to find the next AJ Styles, the next Bobby Roode, the next Samoa Joe. Getty Images AJ Styles enjoyed a fine career in TNA before moving on to join WWE in 2016 WWE 12 Styles has enjoyed a fine first year in WWE and had a long run as World Champion 
“And at Impact, that’s a big part of what we are doing. From the corporate side to the in-ring product, it’s a restructure, a reorganisation, and we want to make Impact great again.” 
Despite his keenness to help the next generation of wrestling stars in their creative angles, Jarrett’s experience in the business has given his the nous to know when to get involved and when to take a step back and let the individual go with it. 
And one man he is happy to do that with is current Impact wrestler Matt Hardy. 
After making his name as a high-flying daredevil in WWE, Hardy has reinvented himself over the last year in Impact, with his ‘Broken Brilliance’ storyline and his feud with brother Jeff being one of the most-talked about wrestling angles around the globe. 
Jarrett said: “I prefer to call it match-making or booking, because Matt, Jeff and ‘Broken Brilliance’ – they are the creators of that. 
“You just have to put them in positions and let them run with it. I think that’s part of the magic of our business is that we don’t really write stories but document them. 
“Matt Hardy has reinvented himself in a unique way, and with Jeremy Borash and how it is edited, it is groundbreaking and it is revolutionising different story aspects.” 
He continued: “When you look down in history, whether it was The Rock or Stone Cold, they are the perfect example that you can be given the ball, but you then have to run with it. 
“Matt was given the ball, and he ran with it. Rex Features Matt Hardy, right, and brother Jeff were praised for their excellent ‘Broken Brilliance’ storyline WWE John Cena has been a stalwart for the WWE over the past decade Reuters 12 Cena recently equalled Ric Flairs record when he won the world title for a 16th time 
“John Cena has been running with it for 15 years. John Cena is John Cena – it’s really not a character he is playing. 
“So you have to refine who you are as a professional wrestler and convey and connect that to the audience.” 
Competing against the monster WWE is always a major problem for wrestling organisations, but Impact are attempting to do that in more one than one. 
In December, Anthem Sports and Entertainment Corporation announced that they had launched the TNA Impact Wrestling app in the UK and Ireland – available for just £4.99 per month . 
And Jarrett insists that fans who purchase it will not be disappointed. 
“When you think about the body of work over the last 15 years, with the likes of AJ Styles having the majority of his career on there, and Samoa Joe, Kurt Angle, Christian Cage, Team 3D… I could go on and on. 
“There’s over 4,000 hours and that’s just the archive,” said Jarrett. Jeff Jarrett was famed for bashing opponents over the head with a guitar joel.fox@thesun.co.uk Samoa Joe was another star who shot to prominence in TNA before leaving for WWE joel.fox@thesun.co.uk 12 Jarrett says the desire to find the next Samoa Joe or AJ Styles is driving him on to succeed with Impact 
“Here in the UK, you have to tip your hat to Anthem, when they came on board the Challenge deal was already dead. 
“So it’s an avenue to continue to watch Impact and you don’t want to miss what is gonna happen on there in the weeks and months to come. 
“It’s a brand that has been in this market for many years and we have a lot of exciting things that are going to happen. 
“This trip over is the start of some great things to come.” 
Read part two of SunSport’s exclusive interview with Jeff Jarrett on Sunday as he discusses Kurt Angle’s WWE return and why AJ Styles really in phenomenal. The British Bulldog's son Davey Boy Smith Jr appears on WOS wrestling
